title: What are the advantages and downsides of Greek battle tactics? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Phalanx was an inflexible, defensive formation. The Phalanx never really went away (formations such as the schiltrom and shield wall are similar) but it's usage waned for various reasons. If you want to talk about a Phalanx vs a medieval army, the chances of the phalangites are slim. While any competent commander would quickly realize that a head on cavalry charge would be suicide against the phalanx, a push of heavy foot (dismounted knights or similar) could quite easily work it's way into the phalanx. Once the formation is broken, it's very vulnerable. A quick cavalry charge from the flanks and the battle is all but won.  This was the general tactic employed by the Romans against the formation. Their good armor and large shields protected them from the spear thrusts, and allowed them to work inside the phalanx, at what point it was easily beaten. The Romans also fought in much looser formations, meaning they could not as easily be totally broken, and the composition of their armies made them far more flexible.  The Phalanx was also vulnerable to harassing attacks, which the Romans employed successfully against them. The tight packing of the unit and it's lack of mobility meant that skirmishers were far more effective than usual against it. The Phalanx also required a far more disciplined soldier to be effective. Now, if we're talking a Greek era Phalanx vs a Medieval army, the battle becomes even more one sided, as the medieval army has steel weapons and armor against the bronze of the Greeks.  Now, if you want to talk Chinese, you need to specify which era. Chinese armies varied greatly in terms of equipment, strategies and composition during the long history of China. For example, there was a period where Chinese warfare was heavily centered around chariots, which would find little success against a phalanx, and yet other times where they had more horse archers, who would eat a phalanx alive with their mobility.
